step1.sentence: After years of being underpaid and overlooked, she finally decided to know her worth and negotiated a salary that truly reflected her skills.

step2.story: Marcus had always accepted whatever salary his employer offered, never pushing back. But after a mentor told him to know his worth, he researched industry rates and realized he was earning far less than he deserved. He walked into his manager's office the next day with confidence and a counteroffer.

step3.story: For three years, Priya had stayed in a job that drained her, telling herself she was lucky to be employed at all. Her colleague noticed how often she volunteered for extra work without recognition and gently said, 'You need to know your worth.' Those four words stopped Priya in her tracks. She spent the weekend listing her accomplishments, the projects she had led, and the revenue she had brought in. On Monday, she scheduled a meeting with her director and presented her case for a promotion with calm, steady conviction. By the end of the week, she had a new title and a raise that finally matched her contributions.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 자신이 얼마나 가치 있는 사람인지 인식하다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 주로 직장, 인간관계, 협상 상황에서 스스로를 과소평가하지 말고 자신의 진정한 가치를 인정하며 그에 맞는 대우를 요구하라는 의미로 쓰인다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 'worth'는 고대 영어 'weorth'에서 유래하여 '가치, 중요성'을 뜻하며, 'know your worth'는 자기 인식(self-awareness)과 자존감(self-esteem) 담론에서 자리 잡은 현대적 표현이다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 단순한 자기 과시가 아닌 내면의 확신과 자기 존중을 강조하는 긍정적인 어조로, 자신감이 부족한 사람을 격려하거나 부당한 대우를 받는 사람에게 조언할 때 자주 사용된다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: Don't settle for less — know your worth and ask for what you deserve.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 더 낮은 것에 만족하지 마세요 — 자신의 가치를 알고 당신이 받아야 할 것을 요구하세요.
